title: Unable to log in to Bandcamp, previously caused by Firefox reCaptcha issues
content:
Hi! This morning I was unable to log in to Bandcamp - same issue that is described here. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/fix-login-issues-on-websites-require-passwords

"I put in my email and password I click the blue "Log in" button The button greys out into the "Please wait..." button After 10-15 seconds it reverts to the blue "Log in" button without the page refreshing."

I've followed every step on this page: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/fix-login-issues-on-websites-require-passwords

with no success. Bandcamp says everything looks normal on their end and that it's a browser issue. I'm able to log in fine on other browsers and on my phone. Previously this error is associated with a reCaptcha issue on Firefox, but trying to see if there's another fix besides just waiting.

title: History older than six months gone without my consent
content:
I use Firefox on all my computers and phone, because its ability to save my browsing history and sync across devices has been unparalleled. This is invaluable because a certain website I frequent has a nasty habit of eliminating and locking its pages. (I‚Äôve asked them about it and they plan to continue doing this.) Without the exact link and all the metadata from my browsing history, I cannot retrieve those pages.

This past weekend when I went to recover a page, I discovered that FireFox has only six months of my history, not the many years I expected. I checked my pre-update profile, and it had no history either. I have some computers that have been offline for a few months so maybe they have versions old enough to still have my history.

How do I get my history back and how do I avoid FF destroying my history without my consent in the future?

title: Unable to Send DTMF Tones in Google Voice Calls via Keypad in Firefox
content:
Hello,

I am experiencing an issue with Google Voice in Firefox where I am unable to send DTMF tones (touch-tone signals) using the keypad during an active call. This means I cannot navigate automated phone menus (IVRs) or input PIN codes when required.

Issue Details: 

   When I press the numbers on my keyboard or the on-screen dial pad during a call, no tones are recognized by the receiving system.    The issue occurs only in Firefox. The same function works fine in other browsers like Chrome.    I have confirmed that my microphone and audio settings are working properly.    WebRTC is enabled (media.peerconnection.enabled = true in about:config).    The issue persists even in a fresh Firefox profile with no extensions enabled.

title: TheFancyDress Your Ultimate Destination for Fancy Dress Clothes
content:
TheFancyDress is the perfect place to find [[fancy dress clothes|https://thefancydress.co.uk/]] for any occasion. Whether you‚Äôre preparing for Halloween, a themed party, a cosplay event, or a school play, they offer a diverse selection of costumes to suit all styles and preferences. Their categories include historical outfits, movie and TV character costumes, 80s and 90s retro wear, superhero ensembles, and even novelty onesies. With options for men, women, and children, TheFancyDress ensures that everyone can find the perfect costume.

In addition to full costumes, TheFancyDress also offers individual clothing pieces like tutus, capes, cloaks, and vintage-style dresses, allowing customers to mix and match for a unique look. Their wide range of accessories, wigs, hats, and props helps bring any outfit to life.

For those looking for inspiration or advice, TheFancyDress provides a community forum where costume lovers can discuss ideas, share experiences, and get recommendations. Whether you‚Äôre a beginner or an experienced costume enthusiast, this platform is the ideal space to exchange tips and showcase creative outfits.

With high-quality fancy dress clothes, a variety of categories, and an engaging community, TheFancyDress makes dressing up fun and effortless for any event.

title: How to Detect When the Print Dialog is Closed
content:
I would like to find a way to detect when the print dialog is closed in Firefox (whether the user clicks "Print" or "Cancel"). My goal is to automatically close the opened tab once the print dialog is dismissed.

Currently, I trigger the print dialog like this: var wdw = window.open(fileUrl, '_blank'); if (!wdw) { 

   onError();    return;

} setTimeout(function () { 

   try {        wdw.print();    } catch (e) {        onError();    }

}, 100); However, I haven't found a reliable way to detect when the print dialog is closed so that I can close the tab accordingly.

In Chrome, I was able to achieve this by monitoring focus events and checking document.activeElement. This allowed me to determine when the print dialog was closed and automatically close the tab afterward. However, this approach does not seem to work in Firefox.

Is there a way to track when the print dialog is dismissed in Firefox?

title: Update today seems fishy
content:
Long story short (as possible):

Windows 11 Home, Firefox version 135.0, File version 18.5.0.0, Product version 18.05

Opened Firefox first thing as soon as PC was turned on today. Immediately prompted for an update. It's Mozilla/Firefox. I didn't question it. I did the update and it asked me to download a file. "I trust Mozilla. OK". It downloaded a Firefox Installer.exe file. The same as the one I installed back in 2022 when I set up this PC. I noticed it was a duplicate because (1) followed the file name. "Odd, but okay...it's Mozilla/Firefox. I trust it"

Then I tried to use Firefox and no matter what website I tried to go to I got a "Gah. Your tab just crashed" on the page. It had "Restore crashed tabs" options but nothing worked. All led back to "Gah. Your tabs..." Thinking about the same Installer.exe file and its (1), I checked the Firefox update history. Nothing for today. I then opened the Properties of the original 2022 Installer.exe and the one today. All were the same except 1) - the 2022 file is 325KB and the (1) file from today is 364KB, and 2) - under Digital Signatures, the Digest algorithm is "sha1" in the 2022 file and "sha256" in the (2) file from today.

I didn't know this Ask a question/forum was here or I would have inquired here first. Instead I turned to Reddit's Firefox group using my phone before I did anything on my PC. I spec'd out the details of the day and was assured by two people to do a restart of Firefox. So I did. Yup, that seemed to fix the issue. And off I went with the stuff I'd originally had in store for my day. Until I had different/unrelated need to view my Downloads and I see a FireFox Installer(2) that must have crept in when I did the restart. There was no notification/prompt or request to allow. It just showed up and I wouldn't have known about it unless I checked my Downloads folder.

Until someone tells me otherwise, I'm staying off Firefox. Two .exe Installer files downloaded for a simple update? One which I authorized/allowed but the other sneaking in when I restarted Firefox? Not to mention the tabs not loading until I did the restart which if legit needed, Firefox didn't prompt me to do? That doesn't sound like normal Mozilla/Firefox behaviour. None of today's events do.

So...is this fishy like I think it is? Fishy or not, what's the best thing to do? I'm okay with computers but DEFINITELY NOT an expert. Hence me being here and asking what to do. Guidance needed. Help?

I wrote out the OS details and specs of the browser. I think that's all that anyone would need but if I'm wrong, don't hesitate to ask for more.

Thanks folks.
